@chetanmeh I was playing around with different memory limits and memory requests. My suspicion is that the `pages` array gets too large if a lot of memory pages have to be allocated.

Look at following example (memory limit for this run was 512 MiB) - please note that the `rss` output from below seems to be inaccurate:

```
[
  "2018-12-04T15:02:01.184725065Z stdout: helloEatMemory: memory 450MB",
  "2018-12-04T15:02:01.24936757Z  stdout: helloEatMemory: memoryInB=471859200, memoryInPages=115200",
  "2018-12-04T15:02:01.750035755Z stdout: helloEatMemory: pages.length=115200",
  "2018-12-04T15:02:01.750560738Z stdout: helloEatMemory: completed allocating memory",
  "2018-12-04T15:02:01.752678064Z stdout: { rss: 547438592,",
  "2018-12-04T15:02:01.752698276Z stdout: heapTotal: 59875328,",
  "2018-12-04T15:02:01.752701533Z stdout: heapUsed: 32053224,",
  "2018-12-04T15:02:01.752704112Z stdout: external: 471876284 }"
]
``` 

I think that we need a different approach to reference the allocated objects to prevent them from being garbage collected or slightly increase the size of blocks.
Does it help to use a different language/a binary to exhaust the memory?
Or may be we revert to array push based approach which seemed to pass for now in few runs

I wanted to do this in addition to another problem, that I detected, but I never had the time to work on the review.
But what needs to be added to this PR before it can get merged:
- Adapt max allowed request size in ingress
- Adapt the max allowed size of requests in the controller (or at least check, that larger actions are no problem)
- Add a test, that it is at least possible to create an action if it has a size just beyond the limit (?)

If you want, you can also copy and adapt the following test to ensure, that the database is able to store actions with the configured size. https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3835/files#diff-522299b4c416d089f4c75c9189447452R207
But if you have a system test, what would be better, you don't need it, of cause.

@cbickel  For now our requirement is more about reducing this limit. Hence kept the scope small for this. To enable a simple one config switch to allow larger code size would need more effort (as you did in other  PR).

Ok, I agree, that the risk is much lower on only reducing the limit.
But on making it configurable, someone could also increase it and be disappointed, if it doesn't work for whatever reason.
So I'd suggest to require it to be lower or equal to 48.

But I think adapting the request size in nginx and controller should be part of this PR anyway. Because this is a protection. There is no need for requests with a size of 50MB if it is allowed to create actions with a maximum size of 10MB. This request can already be filtered out in the front door.

> So I'd suggest to require it to be lower or equal to 48.

Makes sense

> But I think adapting the request size in nginx and controller should be part of this PR anyway. 

Not sure on that part. If someone is trying to lower it then he can modify the other settings as well on his setup. For e.g. in our case we do not leverage the out of the box ansible books (and probably same things stands for kube deployments). So we can keep the default setting as is and just provide a way to make it configurable with the understanding that a system admin tweaking this also adapt other settings (possibly document it in conf file as a note)

I'm currently working on a variant that uses an upper bound for the number allocations - implying that there is also an upper bound for the array storing the references to all allocated blocks. With this approach, the size of the array has less impact on the overall memory consumption.

it is better to output below warning log when too many request happened

Seems like Kamon has changed the [metric naming convention](https://github.com/kamon-io/kamon-datadog/pull/20#issuecomment-391419144). Earlier it used to include the metric type/category as part of name like `openwhisk-statsd.invoker0.counter.database_cacheMiss_count` and now its dropping that which lead to error in our case like 

```
[2018-12-11T15:05:44.284Z] [ERROR] Cannot define metric [database_getDocument_error] as a [Counter], it is already defined as [Histogram] 
java.lang.RuntimeException: Cannot define metric [database_getDocument_error] as a [Counter], it is already defined as [Histogram] 
	at scala.sys.package$.error(package.scala:26)
	at kamon.metric.MetricRegistry.lookupMetric(MetricRegistry.scala:83)
	at kamon.metric.MetricRegistry.counter(MetricRegistry.scala:48)
	at kamon.Kamon$.counter(Kamon.scala:82)
	at kamon.metric.MetricLookup.counter(MetricLookup.scala:41)
	at kamon.metric.MetricLookup.counter$(MetricLookup.scala:40)
	at kamon.Kamon$.counter(Kamon.scala:32)
	at org.apache.openwhisk.common.MetricEmitter$.emitCounterMetric(Logging.scala:222)
```

So we would probably need to do that on our side

Discussed this with @ivantopo on [gitter](https://gitter.im/kamon-io/Kamon?at=5c0f880a80986419d572ba8f) and it seems we would need to take care of the naming part in our side as there is a conceptual change in way Kamon modes metrics. 

Would modify `MetricEmitter` to include metric type

The issue is resolve, because I need to configure Kafka in hosts file as well:

```
; the first parameter in a host is the inventory_hostname

; used for local actions only
ansible ansible_connection=local

[edge]
172.17.0.1          ansible_host=172.17.0.1 ansible_connection=local

[controllers]
controller0         ansible_host=172.17.0.1 ansible_connection=local
;
[kafkas]
kafka0              ansible_host=172.17.0.1 ansible_connection=local
kafka0              ansible_host=<IP of VM1, where kafka is running>

[zookeepers:children]
kafkas

[invokers]
invoker0            ansible_host=172.17.0.1 ansible_connection=local
invoker1            ansible_host=<IP of VM2, where invoker1 is running> ansible_connection=ssh

; db group is only used if db.provider is CouchDB
[db]
172.17.0.1           ansible_host=172.17.0.1 ansible_connection=local

[redis]
172.17.0.1          ansible_host=172.17.0.1 ansible_connection=local

[apigateway]
172.17.0.1          ansible_host=172.17.0.1 ansible_connection=local
```

CouchDB needs to be configured in db_local.ini:
```
[db_creds]
db_provider=CouchDB
db_username=whisk_admin
db_password=some_passw0rd
db_protocol=http
db_host=<IP of VM1, where CouchDB is running>
db_port=5984

[controller]
db_username=whisk_local_controller0
db_password=some_controller_passw0rd

[invoker]
db_username=whisk_local_invoker0
db_password=some_invoker_passw0rd
```

Each of the VMs, where invoker is running, has to be able to access all the other VMs(at least the VM, where Kafka and CouchDB), and be accessible by SSH.
The test coverage is missing some of the error handling and all the Kerberos/SPNEGO code. Is it possible to test Kerberos/SPNEGO with TravisCI?

spans are sent to Zipkin server in async mode once they are created. Can you share your zipkin settings in application.conf ? It will help to debug any issues.
@cbickel Would you be able to review this PR?

One workaround for now is to set `kamon.statsd.simple-metric-key-generator.include-hostname` to `false` which will remove the hostname part of the metric name. It doesn't add any tags for the controller/invoker instance ids but for overall metrics it works. This should also be easier to implement in a backwards compatible way if tags are added to the current metrics so it's only additive. Then setting `include-hostname` to `false` will satisfy systems that need static metric names.
